article.title: Detector efficiency and exposure of Tunka-Rex for cosmic-ray air showers

multiple_choice_question.text: What effect does increasing the number of antenna stations per cluster have on the aperture of the Tunka-Rex array?
choices: Decreases the aperture.
No significant effect.
Increases the aperture.
Makes the aperture radially symmetric.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the "effective detector radius" represent in the context of the Tunka-Rex array\'s efficiency?
choices: The physical radius of the entire antenna array.
The radius beyond which the detection efficiency drops significantly.
The radius where the density of antenna stations is highest.
The minimum radius required for detecting any cosmic ray signal.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is using modified geomagnetic coordinates (cos θ, sin α) advantageous for describing the Tunka-Rex detection efficiency?
choices: It simplifies the visualization of the efficiency cut-off.
It reduces the computational complexity of the simulations.
It eliminates the need for considering the Earth\'s magnetic field.
It allows for a direct comparison with optical and particle detector arrays.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the exposure (ε) of the Tunka-Rex detector primarily depend on?
choices: The average temperature and atmospheric pressure during observations.
The geographic location and altitude of the detector array.
The detection efficiency, observation time, and effective area of the detector.
The chemical composition and density of the Earth\'s atmosphere.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from the cumulative exposure plot of the Tunka-Rex detector (right panel)?
choices: The detector\'s exposure has remained relatively constant over the years.
The upgrades to the instrument have led to an increase in the overall exposure.
The detector is most sensitive to cosmic rays with energies around 10^16 eV.
The detector is primarily limited by the uncertainties in the energy scale.
